Ru9wsB3QMlsB-yU8L-XE5w.text: I love this place Would love to see more variety on the menu (for those who are not adventurous with trying new dishes) Of course there is burger on the menu but always good to see more than one safe option Always recommend it although booking a table lately has been a bit of a chore

8LiFq4efNxtS3TUO8vHG_g.text: Even after five years of living in London I am always amazed at the overwhelming attitude of wait staff that they are somehow doing you, the customer, a favour.  Last I checked it's called the SERVICE industry and the customer is your job.I made a brunch reservation here for my birthday based on a friend's colleague's recommendation.  There were 7 people and we had to ask repeatedly and waited about 20 minutes for a menu.  I should also add the brunch menu is small and mostly egg or meat dishes.  The waiter acted like he was completely inconvenienced when we flagged him down to order.  One of my friends simply wanted toast with scrambled eggs without the smoked salmon on offer.  You would have thought we asked for his first born.  I finally said to him "Can't you just leave the smoked salmon off the plate?  We will pay the same price!"  His response, "ugh, ok fine." and walked away. The icing on the cake was when some other woman came to collect the payment and we didn't leave a tip.  "Why are you not leaving a tip?" she asked.  We told her the food was ok, but service was not and the waiter could have been more helpful and friendly when taking our order.  Rather than apologise or find out more she simply said "Right", took our money and walked away. Not impressed.  If you check their facebook page you will find many other complaints about service and offers to call the manager.  Don't bother, just find somewhere else to enjoy your brunch.

9x_KMbUgwxpyvMCPxNC0eQ.text: Really nice brunch! My eggs royale was delicious and looked appetizing - no complaints. I'll have to come back for the pancakes. And for the chorizo that I hear is amazing. Next time I'll also be sure to try one of the juices that sounded really good and creative (and filling) though this particular day I needed to get my caffeine in (also great btw, including the foam design). Liked the decor and definitely would want to come back for dinner or even just a drink. As much as I liked the communal atmosphere via the long tables, I did feel a bit too close to my neighbor immediately in the next seat, especially since the company I came with sat opposite me (farther than my next seat neighbor which required repeats and conversing over our neighbors).

RmVZjuNozlvPL7wh_qUpNw.text: Lovely venue, friendly staff, great food. What more could you want?

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Brilliant bartender - don't miss the Riding House Cafe!

j5EHgN9HGATayx6jsUR4hA.text: We had the most odd experience here.  The food firstly was fine - nothing to write in detail about. But our waiter was weirdly vacillating between over-friendly, nosy and even smug/superior.  Very confusing. We got taken care of by someone else towards the end of our brunch so it was ok in the end, but I wouldn't return. Didn't love the decor either :(

LEqAZ0wim0a1FwihDQMx8g.text: Excellent food and drinks in a very cool environment. Recommended for a wet brunch!

iOCg-l2Pj67RVrcupglLug.text: Come here for brunch... the chorizo hash brown is amazing. fact. ... but book your table in advance as they get full up a few days before the weekend!

hNLaKw80feS3-JEK2UbO_g.text: Went for coffee with a couple friends. The food and drinks were tasty, especially the iced chocolate. The coffee and walnut cake was a tad rich but the banana cake was quite scrummy. Staff were not as friendly as they could have been and there were no smoothies and a lot of the menu was not available past 4pm which seemed weird.

pFtK_KLiBVI6vZkj7NZMnQ.text: I don't get why this place is so busy.I wanted to come for brunch on a Saturday but found when I tried to book Friday night that the only availability was for 9am. Okay, fine. Breakfast, it is!Arrived at 9am, and the place was empty.The menu featured your bog-standard breakfast/brunch fare with one or two more inspired options. I opted for poached eggs on wholemeal toast (£5.50) with a side of streaky bacon (£3), along with a white americano (£2.30). The eggs were perfectly poached and covered with a sprinkling of chopped chives, sitting on a single slice of relatively small wholemeal toast. I was a bit disappointed, I won't lie. The streaky bacon was perfectly cooked and actually came in an impressive serving size. The americano was far and away less enjoyable than the americano I got from Kaffeine across the street prior to breakfast, which had the same price point of £2.30.But what I really don't get is the fact that the place was still half empty by the time I left at around 11am. Perhaps don't believe them when they say they don't have any bookings for weekend mornings and just show up and see if you can get a table. Or perhaps just sit at the bar - it would probably have been less cold than our table that was constantly barraged by blasts of cold air from the perpetually open front door.And the service was just the wrong side of stuffy and uptight. Although I suppose it could be argued that there is never a good side of stuffy and uptight. What I'm saying is that the service was stuffy and uptight, alright?There's certainly better value-for-money breakfast/brunch places in London than this one. And you won't even have to book. Or worry about the draft. Or put up with aloof, inattentive service. Try Ozone, Caravan or Workshop Coffee for a start.

3fFHsKwteKr34pY7DsLEmQ.text: According to expectation. Not great. Managed to get a  seat on a Sunday without reservation.  Waiter got the orders wrong twice. Ham and pea soup tasted great despite looking a little watery than normal.  Mac and cheese fritter was well balanced and not too rich. I liked it. Roast beef with Yorkshire pudding was disappointing.  Beef was okay but the sauce and pudding were below average.

ql9RySYt4XW_ehIhmWqhjg.text: The name café feels a little bit misplaced here as this is much more like a bistro. There are a selection of large and small dishes available for lunch, starting from just £3 a dish.The dishes were all delicious, absolutely packed with flavour. Each small dish contained only a few ingredients and they were all very present in the flavour.The most striking thing about the Riding House Café is that it's just full of beautiful people. The staff and most notably the customers are all stunning. It's a fantastic place to just go have a couple of dishes and people watch.

BP_Q8lwlaCFR_9IQeewA_A.text: This is the best new place i have been too since moving to London 5 years ago and eating out plenty..... i thought i hated going to SOHO but this place has changed my mind.They have the best selection of cocktails..... savoury, sweet and extra special like one that comes in a tea pot puffing out dry ice like smoke with tonic instead of milk. All inventive and fresh ingredients. Both the food and drinks are very fair prices .. with the quality i would expect everything to be more expensive... but the fact that it isn't makes me want to go there all the time.Sitting at the bar watching food come out.... even as a vegetarian couldnt help finding the meat to look beautiful and delicious. I had the veggie tart.. every bit of which was just perfection. There are also lots of light bite options perfect for accompanying drinks. The menu is packed without being overwhelming or confusing.The hot fudge sundae with honeycomb chunks covered in hot chocolate might have been the best thing i have ever had in my life.All the servers and staff were so nice... really attentive and respectful when you don't want the attention. Again.. would have expected it to be a bit snooty but did not find that at all. Also you can see into the Kitchen and all looks so perfectly relaxed and clean... even on a sold out Saturday night all seemed to be beyond in control.Down to the details again.. the bathroom has the best smelling handsoap / lotion ever... and personal hand dryer, sink, mirror in each stall which is really the best thing ever.Literally cannot find one fault in the place.

Gwuo2Ffk8ZjuyXCpxnnW8w.text: This place was awful. We arrived at 5:30pm on a Sunday & the place was empty, before we sat down we jokingly said to each other "I wonder if they'll be able to seat us". Yet, when we asked for a table they acted like they had to see if they had room for us when the whole entire restaurant was free. When over 80% of it was empty. The wait staff was pretty incompetent and they seemed to be arguing with each other and even though there was barely anyone there the whole time we were there they were less then helpful & numerous times ignored us. They started serving dinner at 6pm we asked if we could order some small plates until 6pm and then order dinner, the waitress said she had to check and see if they needed a table (which we had just sat down at), to which I replied "you mean you were going to kick is out in less then 30 minutes?". It was some of the worst service I've had in a very long time, which is why I felt compelled to write a review. Also another server did not speak English, which is fine except he got our order wrong three times because of it, you should at least learn the language of the menu if you are going to be a waitperson. The food itself was mediocre at best, we were planning on staying for dinner but the shoddy food combined with the horrible service we decided to leave and had a wonderful dinner elsewhere.

KXgJ3cuY8gDU-w7eZbMVvA.text: Excellent food and atmosphere. We were lucky to walk in and be seated without a reservation. The pancakes with berries are fluffy and light and the cream top is delicious... No syrup needed. The Benedict was great as well. Would love to return.

aVqOjfcp-te1zHFqBPSHAw.text: Amazingly varied breakfast menu, I had the kedgeree, which was superbly cooked with a generous amount of smoked haddock. Lots on offer for vegetarians and all in a relaxed atmosphere with attentive, friendly but not overbearing staff. Will definitely be going back with friends

7cX635vokFnt-iun81exdA.text: RHC has gone downhill. Service is AWFUL and prices continue to rise. One server spilled a glass of water on the guest next to us. Our server didn't take or order or bring the bill within 15 minutes. And yo food is no longer impressive or presented well. The plate with my eggs benedict was actually wet - yay for soggy bread!

Zt3D9M6PJalghbRuA7bndA.text: Excellent ambiance, great drinks and very good food.  The Riding House Cafe is a go to spot for out of town guests and business lunches.  The food is generally really good, but they do have some items that suck from time to time - avoid the Lobster Lasagne!

_YTPUourambYFxqRcymj1g.text: I hate to say it, but I didn't really have much fun here, despite the manager being VERY nice.It was during the testing phase, so our bill was 50% off the prices on the menu - but had I been paying full price I wouldn't have been happy.We had the salt cod fritter to start (which was very nice indeed), but didn't go for the full three small plater starter concept that our waiter suggested. He didn't seem to understand the menu itself too much (probably a reflection of how new the place was at the time), but as such had to repeat our order back to us several times before he got it right.Then we had sirloin steaks with fries and bearnaise, which just left me a little uninspired. The meat was overdone (since I'd asked for it medium rare), the sauce was tasteless and my chips were soggy. I *love* good steak, and was really disappointed.We then sampled a raspberry and rhubarb fool, and a honeycomb sundae. The former was fine, but just fine - and the latter was way too sweet and busy.Shame, since it's so close to where I work, but I haven't been back since and don't intend to. I'd rather see them do tapas really well, or a more traditional menu, not both with less than impressive results.

3YyQgJYLdi2r8BGIw3cUGA.text: I found this place always good. Probably the best beef wellington in all London and, if you want a real cappuccino ask for Simone

UJklTf6xXwty4awc7ZAETA.text: Great way to start the day - I was full all day after eating their full and proper breakfast. Loved the decor inside as well.

LobWwhcad1NNTKYR7cJdQw.text: I have been to the Riding house cafe a good few times now. And I am still, to this point, slightly unsure of whether I am completely sold on what they have to offer.I have had incredibly good visits here and have felt that the standard of food and service are well worth the pricetag.I have had just as many visits where I have finished my meal and thought "Wow, that was bland. Holy cow, that is a large bill for average food".Hence, the Riding House Cafe gets three stars.On my last visit, the service was pretty shocking. Our waitress seemed to be half asleep/still drunk from the night before/stoned. She was a friendly person, but totally inept. We waited ages to place orders and there were many instances where we just gave up on additional drinks orders, as she was not paying attention. The final insult was having to wait an eternity for the bill to arrive and have a large amount of service automatically placed on the total.There are some really good. Items on the menu and these are the components that have made me return time and again. The drinks are pretty good, but definitely overpriced.The decor and ambience here are very good, but most definitely not the place to come if you feel like having a quiet breakfast or dinner. The open plan kitchen and high ceilings, really exemplify the "clatter factor"!The Riding House Cafe is potentially a really great place. However, I expect more for this pricetag.

atHPtFWXLb4LYE9io6ZliQ.text: I have been here a couple of times now, so feel well placed to write a quick review.RHC is absolutely brimming with media types in the mornings, all striking deals and quaffing Earl Grey tea. They do everything from eggs on toast to kedgeree, with a couple of things on the breakfast menu that make it through to the lunch/brunch menu too.Talking of lunch...RHC is absolutely brimming with media types in the afternoons, all striking deals and quaffing vin rouge.It's once the aforementioned booze is flowing that this place gets a bit better, in my opinion. That's because they've an extensive cocktail list, serve local beers, have lots of wine to choose from and it's a very nice atmosphere to wind away a few hours.

PWi0_8B7udS9muebIUiHTQ.text: Lovely.... almost!I really enjoyed my first visit here and would happily go there again.The only downside is how anal they are about bookings. They give you your 90 minute slot and at the end of it they kick you out! I appreciate they get busy but we were told the guests who had booked our table had arrived so we had to leave, even though the table next to us (also for 2 people) was clearly available, and they could have seated them there instead and let us stay for a few minutes longer.But the atmosphere is lovely, the food is delicious and the staff are great (until they tell you to get lost)!

9hbgKJoX2DM5QdpOiNIjUQ.text: My friends living in London took me to this place for brunch on a Saturday morning and it was great.  I had the chorizo hash and fresh cucumber and pear juice which were both flavorful but still light..  The seating was very tight in certain parts of the dining room and was almost impossible to get in and out of.

pjdMVyS_HRalowK_tnJmSw.text: A few times a year, I'm lucky to have my travels take me through England. But every single time, without fail, all of my daft American friends want to go someplace and have fish and chips. "Hey, I heard this place has fish and chips." "Have you had the fish and chips here?" "Man, we gotta go into London and get some fish and chips." We're in one of the largest cities in the world; I think we can do a little better.Which is why I was lucky to have a local friend take us to Riding House Café, not because it's good British food, but because it's good food, period. British-influenced, almost certainly, but like much modern cooking, there's a wealth of other influences in there, too.There were five of us, and we decided to go to town on the small plates. We must have tried half the menu, and while there were certainly favorites (the pork belly was cooked perfectly) and even a few flops (the heirloom tomato side was more of a salad, and was pretty light on the tomatoes), the overall consensus was very good. I would say that what struck me the most was the timing on when the dishes were brought to the table - it was done in two waves, and I think more thought could have been taken to figure out which plates would have been more appropriate to being out first. As it was, we were hit with all of the heavy meat dishes during the first wave, and after cleaning those, a lot of the veg came out in round two. I would have liked to have had that reversed.Without reservations, we were able to walk into the restaurant and grab a table with the explicit instructions that we had to be finished within an hour and a half because the table was then reserved. We were only twenty minutes late, for which I do feel a bit badly, but I put just as much blame on Riding House for making their food so tasty. Sometimes, as much as we might try, you can't rush a good meal with friends.

1wk03Ivv0woihIsgYIuGUA.text: Really like this place! Went up to London early morning and headed to oxford street. Needed something nice to brighten up my day so I searched for a breakfast restaurant. The food was really good! Highly recommended. Also, the atmosphere is great. Friendly waiters as well!! :)

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

Cmip72E--zQOZglh-J-lDw.text: This place came high recommended by a colleague and I had to make bookings two weeks in advance. That to me is a sign that this is a good restaurant. So I was really looking forward to trying it out. I loved the space as soon as I walked in, it has that rustic comfort that I favor. However, I was quite disappointed with the food. We went on Sunday at noon and I was hoping to have the avocado toast that was so talked about. However, I was informed that was for breakfast and they don't serve it for brunch. What? That is very strange to me. You really can't serve me the toast that was available just 30 minutes ago? Oh well, so the group of us ordered salads and some other small dishes to share. The salads were fine, but the small dishes were quite mediocre.

olNRnfxwi58Q3myi8h536A.text: So disappointing. I was looking forward to this Sunday brunch having lots of good things about the place.First we book a few days in advance and could only get a table at 2pm. I chose the scrambled eggs and smoked salmon while my friend had the hashbrown chorizo. There was barely anything on my plate and it was put together in the most simplistic way. It looked like my 17 years old brother had cooked eggs and thrown on the plate two slides of smoked salmon and a piece of white baguette. Awful.I asked for a fruit salad and they said they do not have fruit salad in the brunch menu? really what kind of brunch menu does not have fruits?I only give two stars because my friend seemed satisfied of her hashbrowns and mini donuts for dessert. Otherwise it would have been one.In a nutshell: I left hungry

789YxVKaik_sdI0v3seHfw.text: On a lazy Sunday morning, my companion and I made this a destination for brunch-he had been here before, but warned me that it was always crowded and had advised me to get a reservation before arriving. Upon our attempt to actually book a table the previous night, we unfortunately discovered that the place was booked solid for the time that we wanted (around 10am) and there were no other times within two hours available.Undeterred, we made our way over and were informed that there was a table for two available, but we had to leave by 12:45. That was fine. The reataurant was absolutely PACKED--due to the silence in the streets surrounding it, I was prepared for an equally silent restaurant, but it was buzzing with full tables. The menu is easy to read and includes a wide variety of breakfast and brunch options, as well as an all-day menu that wasn't open for Sunday brunch. THe prices range from £6 to £10 for a main--I, from starting a vegan diet two weeks ago, could only have the avocado on toast--I ordered that with a side of mushrooms (2£ is a bit of a hefty price to pay for about three large mushrooms though) and an apple, beetroot, carrot, and ginger juice.The toast came with a lemon wedge and a little pot of vinegar (I was a little confused about how to eat it, but upon sprinkling a little on the toast, it definitely brightened the flavor and you could definitely taste the black pepper). The juice was cold pressed and absolutely delicious, as were the mushrooms.The service was superb--our water glasses were filled multiple times and the servers all seemed pleasant and happy to serve us.

4rDCpUyrjvjB0YZPyxoy_w.text: Mediocre at best.  Over salted food, bland salad.  Menu is deceiving!  Waiter not knowledgeable about gluten free items.  Nice setting when you walk in.  Let Down.

7ky51PFqAa_ZByUo8nihPQ.text: Have wanted to go here for ages for brunch and today was finally the day and what a great disappointment! From booking - which we did a few days before and could only be allocated a slot at 2pm so were starving when we arrived - to the brunch choices which were few and far between, I've been to cheaper and smaller places with better and more extensive choices and to the portions - small to say the least and we were two women dining so I can't imagine how guys would deal with it!  I had the large eggs benedict and PB& J to drink which were both delicious but the food too small a portion. My friend however had a salad with king prawns and we were disgusted when the bill came to see that her salad was £9 before they added the prawns which then were £4 more! When it came time to pay we were then interrogated as to why we didn't want to pay the discretionary service charge and we said about the portions and salad cost, etc. Also we didn't feel the service we received was worthy of a £5 charge especially as we were served by three staff and it wasn't exceptional and one had a bit of an aloof attitude and there was the feeling that you were being rushed in and out. We liked the furniture and distressed / retro design of the restaurant but I wouldn't return and was highly disappointed and hungry after my first and last visit. Such a shame! Very close walking distance from Oxford Circus tube station.

4-oKaMJNH2Y9QUzBu2u1Lg.text: I've had two meals at Riding Horse Cafe. One really delicious and one that was absolutely dreadful. For my second attempt I found the portions to be tiny and expensive. I got two side plates for 12 pounds and the amount of food I managed to consume was the size of an apple. AN APPLE! The waitress was lovely and was kind enough to constantly refill my glass with water. My glass however was filthy. The woman at the table next to me found a fly cooked into her hamburger. Not exactly appetizing. My food appeared to be fine (except for the lack of food to consume). I think this place is really good for brunch. Brunch is fabulous. I will try again but not for dinner. Most likely brunch or breakfast.

mMusmy5li-se6MpVEAIkcA.text: I always come back to Riding House Café. Why? Well, the food is always good and I really adore the place. The decor is beautiful and smart - and you can sit around communal tables, at the bar, in the lounge, in the restaurant. Everything is possible.

dUqKeDSccx19DOF6jlOQhw.text: I expected the food and service to be a bit more on-point given the lovely restaurant design and its reputation but was disappointed. Inattentive and slow service; food was served lukewarm; mistake made on one of our orders which took them about 30 minutes to correct (to their credit, they left it off the bill which was a nice gesture). Overall it wasn't terrible, but I think I had too-high expectations that this would be more of an upscale brunch when it seems to be more like a casual diner.

yl13l1Bd-krzHyh6Jvzpjg.text: We came here for a late brunch on Saturday and sat at the bar.  There was a small wait for two available seats, but it was no big issue.  I like the layout of the restaurant.  A big table in the middle, seats at a long bar, and a raised outer platform with tables next to the windows.We ordered a couple of coffees (my usual flat white and an americano for my wife) and we studied the menu.  The pancakes look good - I saw a few people enjoying it when we arrived.  But I ended up getting the scrambled eggs on sour dough toast with salmon and my wife had the chorizo hash brown.  We also got pork belly as a side, which is an unusual option, but one of my favourite things!The food was tasty and filling.  I was actually surprised at how full I was at the end of it.  I even felt a little pork overload, which is definitely not something that I would admit to often!  The service was efficient and adequate.

hZMs7gqs7oRNPLAERAb4ng.text: Great food and great ambiance! We had a reservation for a Sunday at 10:45 and it was a good thing that we did because they were turning people away. Portions a bit small but the food is really good and they have a nice selection of interesting juices. They also have real American pancakes which is hard to find in London. Definitely recommend!

PcH7-BsCd0t1GFE1xbDXaw.text: This place has a great layout and excellent food. The small plates were great, and we had a pile of them with white wine. I am pretty sure we spent a lot of money, but it was worth it. When a few dishes came out that we were not sure about, they remade them. Cool crew, nice upscale layout and feel, and yet a relaxed place to have a drink and grab a bite.

LkgOOu-bLgFdbYx10xVfYQ.text: Top 10 London brunch place (my opinion). Great rustic but classic ambiance. Food is terrific. You will likely see a celebrity or two. If you like to people watch, this is the place. Could not find fault with food, cocktails or service. Cheerful staff! Be sure to book in advance

zv00oNZrBx_bvtlivcCtBA.text: Really liked their Full and Proper English breakfast.  Everything seemed in order and the black pudding was actually tasty.  Service was quick and friendly.  It was walking distance from my hotel, The Langham London.

VTCsGo-42Ki0fwW_CLjRrQ.text: What a terrific experience.  I found this restaurant in a guidebook as I was planning our London vacation.  It was listed as a "burger" joint but it was better than that (although there was a burger on the menu). The small plates were great and the entrees so good that no one even shared a bite! The atmosphere and decor is lively and eclectic. The service was excellent.  I would highly recommend this to anyone in London visitor or local.

EmeRn0YAGxqnVQ15SdcQbQ.text: Food: I ordered the avocado toast and the grapefruit.  The avocado toast is DELICIOUS. The grapefruit was also very good.  I like their take on it with the ginger, sugar and mint.  Drinks: They have great juices and smoothies on their menu.  I ordered the Tricycle which has apple, cucumber and mint. Price: 14.63 GBP for one person. Ambiance: I walked into the Riding House Cafe one morning by myself.  They offered the bar which was fine even though the restaurant was pretty empty. Service: The server at the bar was fine.  She was there to take my order, brought my food, then the check.  Other than that I didn't see or interact with her. Would I go back?  Yes, it's hard to find nice breakfast places and the Riding House Cafe has good food with a pleasant atmosphere.

VwpaBz-H6GSHkCKVBEw8kg.text: Lovely all day cafe / restaurant. I walked in for a breakfast meeting and realised that most people have booked in advance - so do that!!Sat at the bar, just had a coffee and juice, but the food looked pretty good. Service was excellent.

wWMK835z9rVIamFsLKblMw.text: Met someone here for breakfast yesterday. Understood that it's famous for their breakfasts so had reasonably high expectations. This is England after all so expect soft boiled to be made in perfection. So ordered 2 soft boiled eggs and the waiter said it would take 10 min. That should have been the first hint that this is trouble. 15 min later, 3 eggs came with the rest of the breakfast and they are solid as rocks. Yikes. A

GdZM6EaYHjMACjnhqoE_6w.text: Cute place, good brunch and great for people-watching, but the service could/should be better.My first visit was a flop, but that was totally my bad for going on a business meeting. This meant that a) everyone ordered muesli/fruit and no one had seconds, and b) I was too busy scribbling notes to enjoy the food anyway. What was I thinking?!Thankfully I fixed this by taking some fellow double-brunch fans on a Saturday morning. Their eggs florentines and my chorizo hash brown kept us quiet (for once) as we got stuck in; my huge hash brown was happily teamed up with two poached eggs, spinach and mushrooms, but be warned it's pretty heavy. As in, won't need to eat until tomorrow kinda heavy (although I did). Helped it digest with a yummy ABC Ginger juice in an attempt to be healthy (apple, beetroot and carrot I think).For seconds we shared two helpings of the buttermilk pancakes, with berries, clotted cream and pour-your-own syrup - cue some 'strategic' division between three of us (i.e. I nabbed as many blueberries as poss). Try them if you have any room left; firm but fluffy at the same time, they hit the spot for me.We just found the service a bit lax - it started off nice and smiley, but when we weren't ready to order about a minute after we got the menu, that didn't mean they had to give us another 20 minutes to decide! We also got the wrong table's food at first (though these things happen) and it was pretty difficult to get anyone's attention throughout, even though we could see a row of 3 servers chatting at their station on the other side of the room.No biggie really as we weren't in any rush to go back into the monsoon outside, but it did leave me feeling like it lacked a bit of heart, so just falls short of a 4-star 'yay' - given all the inviting cutesy décor inside I think it missed an easy chance to be really charming.

LMbGDn7YW0kZeFpVV2ST7g.text: This restaurant has been on my wish list for a while. I needed somewhere to stop off for a solo breakfast in between appointments and this was perfect for its location. I was welcomed by a very professional hostess who redirected me away from the seat by the smoothie machine to a quiet seat at the end of the bar, where I could read, people watch and eat in peace. I had the chorizo hash brown which was served very hot in a skillet. It was filling and comforting with good flavours. The service was seamless.  I will definitely return to try more of the menu at another time of the day.

Egj1h-PiQATMn9h7fnsZSA.text: If there's one thing I love more than breakfast, it's being out of the office at a working breakfast and the best place for a working breakfast has to be the Riding House Cafe on Great Titchfield Street.If you go mid-week, you'll find tables filled with twentysomething media types brainstorming, networking and working on their big ideas and this day was no different, in fact Abbey Clancey was being interviewed by a journo on the very table next to me! (yes she's more beautiful in real life and no she didn't eat anything!). The menu at the Riding House is pretty varied, you can go for sweet or savoury depending on whether you fancy pancakes or eggs - always a tough choice in my mind - and they do really great smoothies which are served in milk bottles. On this occasion, I opted for the avocado on toast with poached eggs - but i can also vouch for the buttermilk pancakes! And the Chorizo hash browns....and the eggs benedict.....

k3qGLg3jUb-f-fsD3tMLUw.text: Really happy with my supper! The best part was the desert, cinnamon doughnuts!!! They also have a very good service! The only thing that bothered me a nit was the dirty toilets.... However, I do recommend this place! :)

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

9HL4npR3LM8jfIQcMzoCLQ.text: This was a great breakfast stop on my trip to London. I'd seen it written about on Aspiring Kennedy so wanted to try it out. I had the pancakes with clotted cream and a fruit plate. The fruit plate was delicious, but the pancakes were just okay. They had a perfect crunch to them, and the clotted cream was delicious on them, but they lacked just a bit in flavor. Maybe they were light. I still would go back, I'd just order something different. The eggs Benedict others were having looked delicious. The latte was fantastic, and it was a great experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Fruit plate at breakfast. Very pleased with this!
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Latte
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Pancakes with vanilla clotted cream

q6t3t9Htftehz3K11BZg9Q.text: "Do you how you can tell this place is a genuine country pad?" I remarked we entered in search of brunch, "it's the exposed breeze-block ceiling."What can I say, the affected retro/faux industrial interior craze that is sweeping London's brunch venues annoys me. The anxious conformism displayed for one, and the head-in-hands lack of originality for another. At best it seems to result in venues little different from each other. At worst it seems to be prompting some restaurant chains (e.g. Balans) to ditch their strengths (quality, value, service) in favour of apeing  Bill's in all but name.Anyway, I digress. Evidently Riding House Cafe's interior does not break the mould for brunch places. How about its food? Little different I think, ranging from run-of-the-mill (the Eggs Royale I had), to above-average (a 'Super food' salad, the name of which causes me to grimace). Overall? Just about A-OK, but I wouldn't go out of my way to return.

Wr2sJhyNTFQZY0i9CO-sCQ.text: Starting with the refreshing not too thick ABC beetroot , ginger, apple drink and ending the meal with the divine donuts with cinnamon and chocolate sauce on the side. that made it one of my fav in LondonI had their bone-marrow burger with soft bun and succulent taste. the atmosphere is vintigey awesomethe staff were amazing!

ze_foK6y17Wpe66zGnfzyA.text: The food was awesome. The bacon has a great smokey flavor, the pancakes were really good and my hubby loved the eggs Benedict. They have a coat check for cold days and great service.

E13016W86njSuyWp1ZRxzQ.text: The buttermilk pancakes are amazingly delicious. Staff are very nice and it's always nice to grab a bite there whether you're alone or with company.

7d01DX9ZKqGIcSZHhu5PqQ.text: Came here for brunch once and returned many times after. Found it by accident while looking for food on Great Portland Street. The burger was excellent! Loved it.The seabass is also good but its a hassle to fiddle with as it's the whole fish. Everything we ate was a winner.  Spent one NYE here by chance as our last min plans changed and it was such a great time. No ridiculous crowd and a nice chill spot to bring in the New Year. The atmosphere and decor is great! It's not a cheap eat but definitely worth it.If you don't have reservations I wouldn't come during the busy periods because the wait is quite long.

mhvquxuGvl8qpxqt9eiqgg.text: For me riding house cafe has always been a spot to catch up with friends, colleagues - mainly about work related business or job opportunities over a laid-back breakfast and coffee. My four star review may come more from smiling back on past conversations or just the general morning vibe you get during weekday mornings of media/advertising/social folks coming in for business meetings and a chat.Though I've had dinner and drinks a couple times at Riding House, this wouldn't be my recommended time for going. I've found the sharing plate/tapa style comes out too small and are inconsistent with their portions (honestly, it feels the more you drink there the less food you get by the end of the night!).  That being said, if you're craving either British or American style breakfast - this place has got it down. With all the hype (I don't know why) still out there on Breakfast Club - if you're looking for some actually great American style pancakes and French toast - you'll be happier here!

ecGfQraHIgLh9jwvBIBYVg.text: After a thirty minute wait, we got a table at this great brunch spot. I had the eggs hussard, which I thought were fantastic. I was so close to giving 5* for this restaurant, but the other dishes I tried weren't as good. I also got the racer juice (espresso, almond milk, banana, etc) which was surprisingly refreshing. A lot of times espresso flavoured juices can be overpowered by the caffeine but this was well balanced. Would recommend and there is a great coffee shop (Kaffeine) across the street while you wait for your table.

DP5mTJUOm2hyofRt4QOBgQ.text: This is a decent option if you're looking for sustenance and are steeling yourself ahead of a day out on Oxford Street. Far enough away from the crazy tourist crowds to feel like a bit of a local haunt. Also a great jumping-off point if you're spending the day in Regents Park or Marylebone.Came here at 1pm on a Saturday without a reservation, and managed to snag a table for three with the caveat that we had to be out within 1.5 hours. This proved to not be a problem, as the service was fairly swift. I had the chorizo hash, friends both had the avocado benedict - both were fairly tasty. My flat white was pretty average, but had a delicious "Boris Bike" smoothie with almond milk that filled me up almost as much as the brunch itself. Decor was great and staff really friendly.

SxLQ0jI2x_-QAwIeZd8Dtw.text: +Duck roasted potatoes (crispy and fatty!)+Buttered sprout tops (basically fried brussels sprouts)+Mashed celeriac (loved this)+Squid and chorizo salad-Lobster benedict (very stingy portions of lobster)Nice ambiance, service took a while, but great place to sit a while and brunch.

q7CP4XnUncAYwrZrlnmpag.text: Food was decent for the price. The service, however, was shockingly bad. Waited ages for food, for it to be cleared, for the bill. And with service included? Didn't feel that our service deserved the 12.5 percent of our bill, though we could have removed it, we just decided to not dine here again.

MvbEVmH0xsciBJaRCw96Qw.text: Had a great dinner here in a group of c. five people. Very good food, pretty well priced. Excellent service. I quite liked the ambiance as well. Definitely worth checking out.

y21v5NKdpirgm0HOyyTW4g.text: Great stop for a local breakfast. The food is high-quality and thoughtfully presented. Most of the breakfast menu is standard, but with surprising twists and luxurious details.But the real star is the decor. The large space offers stylish seating options (long tables, tiled bar, banquettes) and a retro/repurposed vibe. If the coffee doesn't wake you up, then the taxidermied-squirrel light fixtures probably will.

EO1f7X8SpNOwusUQreVoeQ.text: The decor is pretty awesome, and the staff are pretty attentive and spot on (our water was constantly topped up without having to ask). However they seemed to have gone for style over substance, typified by their menu. There were rather confusing different sections for different times of day. But the worst part was the lack of basic labelling (vegan, vegetarian, gluten free, contains nuts etc) and or any real descriptiors of the food. For example, I ordered the 'Superfood and Herb' salad with added haloumi cheese. The menu had no description of which superfoods were included, and the waitress couldn't shed much light (although I didn't push it). When the salad arrived it was rather conspicuous in it's lack of herbs. The food was however pretty decent. But I don't think I'll be back as I don't like the Russian roulette feeling to the menu. And the annoying loud teenagers with their iPhone.

p2leAHrycgyO6zowMV6F_Q.text: Seriously, don't even bother coming here for breakfast. Worst breakfast ever! The scrambled eggs are a weird colour, consistency and are super salty! Coffee is bad! Well nothing more to say... If you have bad coffee, I am clearly not your target market.

KdJZ94pJE5QjToVnxABmVg.text: Best breakfast place in London. Hands down.I always order the iced coffee and avo & feta on toast.

s3TV8Bsv4Wk7J4ptSokXBg.text: Hands down my favorite brunch spot in London. I highly recommend the pancakes - 3 pancakes topped with clotted cream and strawberries, blueberries and raspberries. I'm also a big fan of the avocado eggs benedict - avocados are very fresh and the eggs are cooked perfectly. Also, definitely try the different teas. I love the mint tea. I recommend making a reservation ahead of time. If you don't, you'll have to eat at the sharing table or the bar - both of which are not bad. Overall: delicious brunch, lots of options, highly recommend

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Avocado Eggs Benedict

WvEdu3eWZwPKrmg9IJFphQ.text: Great choice of savoury breakfast dishes. I had avocado Benedict which was delicious with feta. Perfectly cooked. Very instagramable and super filling. I also had a smoothie which was huge and very nice too.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Avocado Benedict
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Boris bike smoothie

u8iRlVbBoWgM0D6Y0-E30Q.text: Saturday brunch, they were pretty busy and we didn't have a booking but managed to get a table for two after a little wait. Breakfast menu was great, service was attentive and food delicious. Was also good that you can order single eggs benes so you can make room for other delicious treats. You can also get lobster benedicts!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Must try.
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Sourmilk pancakes. Yum.
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Single bene

lrA0fktTKtn8MN0BC5V5HQ.text: I love the interior of this place but I loved that it was open in a seemingly deserted center of town one Sunday morning.I got a full fry up and I liked it very much. Service was frantic but accommodating. Took us a while to get seated it was busy. Good juices and tea to go with it.I'd definitely come again for lunch or it seems like the perfect setting for brunch quite honestly, with some friends.

nuuC0-iqMrIVlAsi7qS0wQ.text: A useful place for meeting friends - central London, some large-ish areas and a nice decor. Definitely a good choice for visiting friends, very much that London feel. Brunch was fine - we both had the french toast and it was nice enough for the price. I'm a big brunch fan and I found a few of the other dishes a bit overpriced and was less than enamoured of the choice.It was busy, no doubt. We didn't book but got a table (well space on a table) for two pretty quickly - any more people and I would definitely recommend booking.Though none of this place screamed 'AMAZING' at me, the location, the size and the swish-ness will likely have me returning.

9VrFygdL2aYxNF2xMDYuPw.text: Good place to get the full English breakfast. Busy place, book a table if you're not here on a weekday.The service isn't good and the coffee is not impressive. Go for the food and get coffee across the street afterwards. The full and proper English is A. Lot. Of. Food, the black pudding is especially good. You can have it without toast if low carb is your style. This will keep you fill for a good amount of time. Not the best English breakfast I've had, but still worth the visit. The hash brown is good, too, according to my partner.

a8T196CeYdnQcBvPd3kspQ.text: Nice meeting place to have drinks. If you have no reservation you get seated at this huge table with other folks. The food is on the pricier but worth every pence. I had the beef Wellington and it is amazing.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Beef Wellingtom

BoJvTIERfqx9dlu81ixJUQ.text: It was okay.First issue was when we arrived, we were told there'd be a wait time (understandable) and would we mind standing where we were until a seat was available for us to wait on.There was a girl by herself behind us who hadn't had her name on the wait list yet, and then a big lady who pushed in front of this girl with her whole family.This immediately pissed me off, and I pointed out she had just pushed in front of someone. She then got rowdy and started insulting me, all the while the door lady was just standing there.We waited for 15 minutes to be seated at the bar...Unhappy about that, when people who had been behind us in the line got actual tables.The menu was ok. The only reason we stayed was that my boyfriend really wanted to try their buttermilk pancakes (which were actually really good).I ordered one eggs Benedict, and after seeing someone's food went by, asked if it was at all possible to change my order. Our waiter/bartender was able to do this which I really appreciated.What I ended up eating was a 'chorizo hashbrown with poached eggs'.Overall it was good, but the entire potato hashbrown was soggy (was it meant to be like that?) and the chorizo left wet patches over it. Eggs were cooked almost perfectly though.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Left: Buttermilk pancakes. Right: Chorizo Hashbrown

0gH29-8DHvOLBtQUFfHNUQ.text: You definitely need to book in advance if you plan to visit this cafe on a weekend! Even on a weekday you are hedging your bets if you expect to just rock up. The service in this cafe is impeccable and it is definitely a good option for taking friends from outside the city. There's a very laid back atmosphere and the decor is really nice too. The only thing is that the service can be quite slow so if you're in a rush, it's not the place to be. As you will have probably had to wait for your reservation, take your time and enjoy the ambiance!I had the chorizo hashbrowns which were really nice as there was plenty of chorizo in them and the hashbrowns were really cripsy. A friend had the eggs benedict which while tasty wasn't very filling and we were glad to have gotten some pastries on the side. The avocado on toast was pretty good! The coffee was average which is a big disappointment. As someone who really likes to get a good kick it was quite weak. The smoothies on the other hand were really flavourful and a pretty good size, even if they are a bit on the pricey side. I  had been looking forward to going here for quite some time and I wasn't disappointed. If I were taking friends from outside the city, this is definitely a good option as it's a nice experience but it isn't the first place I'd rush back to for my usual weekend brunch as it's a little more expensive than other places which are just as good.

46ephQUCf0p3sPbhzs4rHg.text: This was my first brunch stop after arriving in London and I absolutely fell in love. The avocado eggs Benedict was so good, I wish I could have had time to get it again. Guess that just means I'll have to make another trip back!

ALLbOkUOVLzhHl3nwT2vmA.text: I should really change my current crush in my profile to "Chorizo", but I think it might make me sound a bit... desperate.  Yes, I have a love affair with food.The menu sounded delicious and the reviews were pretty good, so again, another bookmark for my weekend in London.  After a restless night at the hotel listening to doors slam, I set out for the Riding House Cafe with my book.  It was busy, but I didn't have to wait for table.  After being seated, I did to have wait to receive a menu, but my glass was filled with water very promptly.  The two tables seated after me were waited on first and I still had not received my menu.When I did receive my menu, I ordered the Chorizo Hash Browns with the poached eggs and mushroom.  I also ordered the Racer Smoothie.  The smoothie came in a glass milk bottle.  I was able to specify soy milk in my smoothie of espresso, chocolate, and banana.  It was nice, not overly sweet.My breakfast came out and it was quite the sight.  I hadn't expected the flash of green from the pile of spinach, but it was a fantastic edition to the spicy chorizo and the rich yolk of the poached eggs.  I was not able to finish, but it was such a satisfying breakfast.  Everything on the plate complimented each other and it really exceeded my expectations.  The price for the meal, smoothie, and an Americano... really good, actually if you are on a budget and have breakfast here, without a lot of extras, you could easily do it for under £10 and be very satisfied.  What if you don't wake up in time for breakfast?  The Chorizo Hash Browns are on the all-day menu!Now if they could only work on the service...

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Chorizo Hash Browns, Americano, Racer Smoothie, and my book =)

R47Z2GBnuY1YOw8R5mDK2w.text: The Riding House provided exactly what I needed at the exact moment I needed it: a fantastic, post-dinner espresso martini.Every time I raised that glorious glass to my lips, the smell of those gorgeous coffee beans hit me and reminded me how awesome espresso martinis can be. I'm not kidding, that was the best-smelling cocktail I've had in a long time.An hour later I was ready to switch to something less caffeinated and the bartender was very helpful in recommending a good segue from espresso booze to sleep (particularly impressive since my gluten-free limitation meant no whiskey or bourbon). In the end we settled on a courvoisier old fashioned. The bar, which runs the length of the narrow restaurant, was packed at 930 but we wrangled a stool (some of the heaviest and most awkward ever) by staying eagle-eyed. By 1130 it had thinned out, we were sufficiently drunk, and we'd enjoyed just the right atmosphere to chat conspiratorially on all things awesome. The Riding House was great for what we were there for: drinks, seats and lively environment.

Dbc1l9e2dP_q5nuhRWDvRw.text: Two pings off the bat for sitting at the bar (alone), waiting for food and being ignored for about 10 minutes. In other words, typical London/Europe.Finally, I ordered the superfood salad (with no description on the menu). A nice-sized portion of broccoli florets, quinoa, red cabbage and sweet potato. I loved the vinaigrette on top. I also had the violetta artichokes, with rocket, lemon and honey. A nice-sized portion again for an appetizer. The flavors played off each other nicely. So expect very good food, but crappy service.

YlelPS02crnVewJa3j45nQ.text: I've visited this cafe twice and really enjoyed it. The staff is friendly and skilled and the food is very good comfort food. I recommend the Duck!

44jdcT73vuxuf2uoO_RaDw.text: Loved the communal table and the spot on drinks. Some seriously delicious cocktails served at the Riding House Cafe, folks. Came here on a recommendation from a local. Must say, I really enjoyed everything. My only small gripe was the chorizo in my chorizo hash. I'm a Sonoran Desert dweller, so I expected a bit more spice and a totally different texture, but it wasn't bad. It just wasn't Mexican, and the hash was not crispy what-so-ever. The poached egg, however, was perfect. Don't get me wrong, I still enjoyed it, but it could be better. Another plus is that we just popped in Friday evening after shopping. No reservation and they were able to seat us. Have to appreciate that.

z_TJ0c1vWzoz6zSeOcu2fw.text: I just love this place. I have been twice now and ready to go back again to try the other menu items. They have a very cute warm and inviting ambiance with a rustic and modern feel.Once we had reservations and we were seated quickly. The second time we came on a Wednesday night with no reservations they told us the wait would probably be an hour but I am pretty sure we only waited about 30 minutes or less and we sat at the bar.The only dish that I don't care for much is the artichoke dip. It is quite tiny and the flavors and textures are lacking. Everything else I have tried though has been delish! Great service too!Clams, mussels, chili and garlic,Artichoke dip, crostiniBarbecued quail, creamed cornChopped salad, avocado, palm heart, radish, dijon dressingChateaubriandPoached Cord Fed Chicken, spring vegetable broth, salsa verde

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

kPICTx83xCzFtmbh3DcX1Q.text: Great for breakfast or brunch. Good food, friendly service, and a nice atmosphere. I had a business meeting here, and it was suitable for that as well.

7sZUAZb8j-7jTjHBlNHMqA.text: We were relegated to the basement in a room called "The Stables." The last time I went to a barn-themed restaurant Black Barn in NYC, we were also there for a solid 4 hours. Not to disappoint, The Riding House welcomed us in at about 5:30pm and finished serving our food around 8:30pm for a 3 course meal. People had already begun to trickle out slowly - first those with kids, then those with lives, finally those stragglers picking away at the last pieces of cheesecake.The ambiance of the restaurant was cool - a single metal pipe connected an overhanging chandelier. The room was wooden (like a barn), chairs made of leather which looked like it could've come out of a car from the '60s and there were photos of horses behind wooden panels.The food was also not bad - beef wellington, carver chicken, hake, kale, wings, artichoke dip, NYC cheesecake. All quite good and would highly recommend it.If you get a chance, come check the place out, just make sure it's a long chance.

Wq91MfLRHz6YLPPPDiOTYQ.text: A lovely breakfast & brunch spot in Fitzrovia! Per TimeOut's recommendation, my colleague and I ordered Riding House Cafe's famous pancakes. It comes in 3's and is served with vanilla clotted cream, maple syrup, and an assortment of berries. The pancakes themselves were delicious, with a texture that is more cake-y than the traditional American version. However, IMO the clotted cream was the real star of this dish.timeout.com/london/food-…

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Buttermilk Pancakes (9.50) - berries, vanilla clotted cream, maple syrup
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Full English (14.50) - streaky bacon, Lincolnshire sausages, black pudding, free-range eggs, roasted tomato, field mushroom, beans, toast
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Smashed Avocado, Sourdough (7) - chilli, tomato

Sc59m_SRecdmGmgQwPEwyA.text: I discovered this place when I was working in Great Titchfield Street a couple of years ago. It's a busy road but not an obvious one, and the Riding House Cafe attracts a crowd of people working nearby - at least during the week, I haven't been here at the weekend.On most visits it has been quiet which makes it great for a casual coffee. Evenings and lunches are a different story and the place can be quite packed.Apparently, they are well known for their pancakes. So much so that they were recommended in a feature about less obvious Shrove Tuesday treats ... should have guessed that this would translate in a bit of a run on pancakes, but didn't! So, this was turning into a bit of a nightmare visit. All tables were booked and the only space available at the bit of the bar that backs onto the open kitchen. Apparently they had hundreds of people come through the door since morning and made use of every chair available, but this wasn't going to work. Then again, the pancakes leaving the kitchen looked amazing ...  note to self for next year, make sure to book a table!!Thanks to the super attentive staff we did get a table after a reasonable wait, just in time for our super berry buttermilk pancakes to be served. Bit of a weird lunch choice (no savoury options, this is not a creperie or Dutch pancake house after all), but delicious!All's well that ends well, we left fat and happy.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

Woaihhl1WBoalPhjWEqz7Q.text: Absolutely delicious, we came for brunch. Pancakes, avocado toast, etc. Try the benedict burger, delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

4t-rwY0AZFcCbD-gkSz1JQ.text: Great breakfast in a really cool space. I had the French toast with clotted cream- delicious. My 11 year old picky son enjoyed the pancakes (sans fruit). My wife loved the smashed avacado on toast with a couple of poached eggs.

M1YpdRwHyiyFCJ-7zYZpfA.text: Came here on two occasions since we were staying down the street.First we came for drinks before dinner and enjoyed it very much.  The old fashioned was made perfectly. I also love the open kitchen so you can see how they prepare the food. It is very entertaining if you are into cooking!The bar staff were very attentive and helpful.The 2nd time we came for breakfast. I ordered the french toast and it was delicious. My fiancee ordered the full english breakfast. It was also very good.The place has a good vibe whether you come for breakfast or drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. English breakfast
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Cool decor
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. French toast

9e1LGyfl2hyIxRkc_gf9fQ.text: I was tempted to have some fluffy pancakes for my Sunday brunch and decided to check this place out after seeing the mouth watering pictures on Instagram. It tastes good at first, but soon you will feel like you are consuming cube sugar. They should cutting half of the sugar amount on their pancakes. Or else, everyone will be leaving their store with sugar rush after finished that plate.

mSHU1Nkuhoy0tS7K4pC5XQ.text: One of my favorite brunch places in London. Go for their porridge with berries or their Eggs Benedict. The place itself is cozy. 4/5 since the quality of service swings a bit.

0XKYCmUlK-EkwHVuAaIQzg.text: Came here to try the beef wellington while in London. Weird interior/furniture, cross between a starbucks (or other cafe), lounge, and diner. Food wise, everything portion wise was small. The "small plates to share" is misleading as in actuality the portion was only enough for 1 person. The beef wellington was also on the small side, and drowned in truffle oil.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

lLK5s3Gt7P0NXcGme0AbtQ.text: My friends know I am a bit nutty, especially when it comes to having Beef Wellington in the UK. After many years of hearing Gordon Ramsay say "it's raw!", "the pastry is too loose", "look how soggy your beef wellington is!", I had to try it myself.When we sat down and made it know that was our purpose there, the server was confident that we would love it...and the verdict is...I didn't love it. It was not any of the comments above, but it didn't knock the ball out of the park. A bit pricey too considering there is nothing on the plate besides a few greens. My particular beef wellington was not tightly wrapped and a little bit cold too.We also ordered the lobster lasagna and it was a bit bland, nothing too impressive. Ordered some small plates. a quail dish and a cauliflower hummus dish, really not a lot going on and very small portions.It was very good ambiance and decor, but would not make a return visit. I was actually quite hungry after the meal, and proceeded to eat a lot of nuts at the bar we went to.

9xl1-Ruo6JBptQ8lBw_g9w.text: Food is very good for brunch. Suggest making a reservation in advance as it gets very crowded. One of the better spots I have had brunch at in London.

BtHPdKoDFDhxyC_NUaWz0Q.text: The quest for the best avocado on toast keeps going - Riding House Cafe does this well: they're putting feta and poached egg on the avocado toast (that is the best combination)It was good but nothing to die for. The rest of the menu was ok (french toast were good but again not amazing) and coffee was a bit weak.It's a nice place for breakfast but maybe not the best one in town.It's hard to get in without a booking, but cool thing is the big communal table that you can't book.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

I7KOjea9HC-iQ5PHXRbJdQ.text: While I visited London, my friend brought me here. I ordered the Beef Wellington with moussaline potatoes. We also ordered a bottle of wine and olives to share. The dish was so delicious and everything melted in my mouth. The meat was cooked to perfection. I definitely recommend this to any Londoner or tourist. Great for dates, groups, or to just chill at the bar. Make sure you make a reservation since it get quite busy.

9DFfcJR3PHp6j587ZMjF8Q.text: Reservation recommended, but you can also wait for half hour and get a table (you can ask for a drink in the meanwhile) the food is very good, eggs florentine in the picture!nice smoothies also!Attention for every little detail, nice atmosphere, tables seem very close one another but they are not!

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. eggs florentine

OHRqONXyN2P26X2b-bXdMw.text: Went for brunch and really enjoyed everything. I ordered the chorizo with hash brown, poached eggs and mushrooms. It came in healthy portions and was very flavourful. I really liked my cappuccino as well. One of the better coffees I've had at a brunch place. Service was good and prompt. Our waitress was polite and very capable at managing all the tables. Ambience was also nice - spacious and well decorated. Would be suitable for any sort of occasion. Overall, definitely recommend it!

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

4k21drkva5HBEg0lzdIh0A.text: Super cosy atmosphere, very friendly and attentative staff, reasonably priced and honestly the best pancakes I've ever had.

5Gkr6vZIqcaCtr1_YJPPfg.text: Came here for brunch on a Saturday morning and was quite pleased. We were meeting some family for a bite and it was a convenient meeting place. The only issue was that they were quite busy and we were lingering over coffee catching up. The server requested that we pay and leave as they needed the table. My only suggestion would be don't come here if you want a long leisurely brunch - they are on quite a schedule.The coffee, juices and smoothies were great. The juices were a little on the pricey side but everyone thought they tasted wonderful.I ordered the crunola parfait and a side of toast. I didn't love the crunola but that was partially my fault. I expected more of a granola base rather than seeds. I should have asked prior to ordering. My cousin ordered the avocado toast and it looked delish! I would definitely be willing to come back for a quick breakfast or a sandwich at lunch. My cousin believes she will be back again as well.

Sl2QpuEUaHPwo8VXhZt4Jg.text: So I saw this restaurant on a couple of lists for the best English breakfasts and fell in love with the pics of the decor. The decor lived up to the hype, the food and cleanliness did not.I had the avocado toast with poached eggs and it was pretty good. My meal mate had the French toast which ended up being cold when she got it. To add insult to injury our cups and saucers and teapots were NOT clean. The service was great. People were pleasant and helpful, and the decor was awesome.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Avocado toast with poached egg.

PLxzEUdgMK8WJ0R_Ygg6FQ.text: Well I have wanted to visit here for a long time and so glad I did it was all it lived up to! I choose some nibbles and my friend had Chorizo croquettes - serve was really good even though we just sat at the bar and was a really chilled ambience even though it was busy. I tried tuna, croquettes and cauliflower all were fresh and full of flavour - I will be back

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. My trio of flavours
Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Trendy sink want this In my home

gPbWeU0YAKHVlCPHX_FI-g.text: A very New York style, beautifully designed cafe/restaurant. The only difference is that they do not do bottomless (all you can drink) brunch.The service has the same attentiveness as a New Yorker Cafe (you wait at the front, they set you, only certain people can take your order and one specific person looks after your area) and you can book a tables even for breakfast. The menu is a little on the ex-y side but you are paying for not just breaky but the whole experience so I think it is worth it. The menu has everything you need to start the day- av (and feta and eggs if you please) on toast, full English, full veg (one of the best that I have ever had), hash browns, bircher and some 'creative things'. All done in a way that is one step up from usual. My only food complaint is that they have not nailed the runny egg. Hence 4 stars. They have a range of breakfast cocktails and, of course, a blood mary that will sort your hangover out. The coffee is pretty good- it's not quite at Australian standard, but it's about a 3.8/5. The seats are super comfortable and all of the furnishings are so soft and hard to pull yourself away from. There is one large table down the centre of the restaurant which is used as a share table, there is seating at the bar (very luxurious stools) and then there is a very, very comfy velvety bench around the side. If you are booking ask for the bench part it's the best for people watching too.

photos.caption: Photo of The Riding House Cafe - London, United Kingdom

opMP4etAX5faBh10EMRXlw.text: Quirky place but I felt a bit intimidated.Bouncer lady on the door and full of trendy twenty something's.Meal was different. One or two very nice and interesting dishes though.Unfortunately after playing the small plates sharing game we also had ordered mains. With deserts and wine the bill came to a rather shocking 85 pounds despite we were on a half price deal!!!If I had been paying full price it would have wrecked the evening.Overall we had a nice time. Would like to go back but will wait for another deal.

DR5xGfK_4lFo382oGdRGgA.text: What a great looking place - the bar is gorgeous the details are quirky and interesting and the place was heaving. The waiter kept putting his hand on my shoulder (I am a straight man and don't like strangers touching me) and the food was a let down. Worth a visit but don't bother ordering anything  your money is better spent else where. The burgers in the pub opposite are better and so is the service.

nSxVtE9_TLyKLPcGgwSaKQ.text: In a word: outstanding.  Anyone who can't / doesn't give this place at least 4 stars has had an off experience.  Its not fancy, its not over the top, the ingredients are plain and simple but its all outstandingly executed.  Whoever thought that someone could reinvent beets and goat cheese?  their version is insane.  As is the Figs with Curds.  And the buck breast might be the best duck I've ever had this side of $30.  Not to rare and not to cooked - perfectly pink.  Incredibly well executed, a real bargain for the price.

c3OdZXfwz2QyD-CD23AL6g.text: This bar/cocktail bar/restaurant/brasserie manages to be all things to all people, and there's always been a great vibe when I've been there  there's lots going on, but the sound levels aren't so high that you can't have a conversation. If you book, you can choose between seats at the long rustic refectory style table down the centre of the room, or individual tables, or seats at the bar. If you haven't booked at busy times, you might be seated at the bar to eat, but it's fine and the waiters always try to fit you in somewhere. I've eaten both from the selection of small plates, and the main dishes  if you are hungry, go for the latter, the small plates are really quite small. The wine list offers good choice at reasonable prices.

l1ChrqpZ1FhniyQUdCCP7w.text: The chorizo hash brown (with portobello mushroom and poached egg) is delicious, they do a mean bloody mary and the decor is great (other than the slightly grotesque stuffed squirrels that form a part of the light fittings) but the service is very poor. Although the restaurant wasn't partiular busy this Bank Holiday lunchtime, we were initially asked every two miutes if we were ready to order yet (possibly due to the 1.5 hour table turnover deadline they state on their website applies at lunchtime) but then, once having made our choices we were left nursing empty drinks glasses as the tables around us  who were seated later than we were  all received their food. Cocktail refills requested as mains arrived were delivered at the same time as the dessert menu meaning we skipped anything else, paid up and went for sweet and coffee elsewhere. A shame, I've been here before and enjoyed it  maybe this was an off day. I hope so but it'll be some time now before I return to find out.

li3uFlS7P5xXOWy558wLLg.text: Complete review and pictures to be found here hungryinlondon.com/2011/… The Riding House Cafe, North of Oxford Circus,is one of the most enchanting places I have been to in a long time. As an all day restaurant it comprises of a more formal restaurant corner,large shared tables perfect for brunch and comfy sofas for the afternoon coffee or pre-dinner cocktail. The overall decor and the attention to detail is remarkable. The generous room shows a number of different textures such as stone,steel,wood and tiles and is filled with antique mismatched furniture interspersed with modern pieces. Wherever you look you can find charming accessories a grandmother lamp,a weird statue or some other knickknack. Particularly thoughtful I found that they disguised the Dixon hand-dryer at the Ladies'with a fake-antique metal cover. So nothing but praise for the interior of The Riding House Cafe. I just wish they had put as much emphasis on the food as they had on their design. This seems to be a common problem also of the other 2 places by the same owner,namely The Garrison and Village East (both at Bermondsey Street). All three restaurants are pushing the boundaries regarding their design and concept,while staying on the too safe side with their food. The Riding House Cafe has just like everybody else at the moment embraced the small plate concept,serving 5 or 6 dishes each for 3,4 or 5 pounds. Instead of entirely focusing on perfecting its 'tapas',it also offers a conventional menu with burgers,steak and fish and chips. We decided to stick with the small plates. The quality of the bread served is very often an omen for things to come and this proved true also for this occasion. Competitively priced for £1.5,the bread was unfortunately bland and starchy. The artichoke puree it came with was ok,but I have no urge to ever eat it again. Our clear favourite was the most low-profile dish we had ordered,namely the roasted butternut squash with sage and chili (3.5). Even though we asked for extra chili,it was not the least spicy,but nevertheless tasted beautiful and fresh and I loved the combination of sage and squash. However,this dish was a very simple one and even I with my very limited cooking skills might be able to pull it off. I have a compulsion to order beetroot when it is anywhere on the menu. The Riding House Cafe beetroot carpaccio (3) came with sheeps ricotta (too mild) and merlot vinagraitte (too sour). With a lot of salt and pepper it was almost decent. The chicory,pear and gorgonzola salad (3) was definitely not the most exciting dish I have ever eaten. It consisted of a few leaves of chicory,some slices of pear and a few cubes of gorgonzola. You might have guessed by now that it didn't come with any additional seasoning,sauce,vinaigrette,. If you like your food very much stripped down to basics,you might really love the dishes at The Riding House Cafe. Or maybe you still mightn't actually. Again on the bland side was the seabass ceviche (5). It was swimming in olive oil but lacked the zesty citrus flavour that I associate with ceviche (ceviche is to my knowledge raw fish that is marinated in lemon juices) as well as some chili. It was by all means edible,it just lacked any kind of wow-factor. The Steak Tartare (5) was again a dish without character. I don't dispute the quality of the meat which was undoubtedly very good if cut too coarsely and consequently 'sticking between your teeth'tough. While I don't like steak tartare that it drowned in worcester sauce or other condiments,I still expect some chili kick or at least salt or pepper Now let's talk about the service. I am very embarrassed to admit that I was scared of the waitress. She was about half my size (and I am not exactly a big girl) but she was so brusque and bossy! She brought us the things that she thought were appropriate very quickly,while we waited in vain for everything else. For example,we never got our salt and pepper (you might have gathered by now that salt and pepper were crucial components of this meal) which I finally had to forage from some table at the other end of the restaurant. She was not exactly a bad waitress,but I am sure she is better in her day job as a prison warden or primary school teacher. It seems The Riding House Cafe is afraid of flavouring and seasoning its food,which is a shame as a lot of the dishes are almost there. I prefer to have a meal with some divine dishes and some that went a bit wrong to small plate boredom. To stand out in the competitive London restaurant scene,one has to take at least a little bit of a risk and this is something The Riding House Cafe is certainly not doing. I would be perfectly happy to go back and spend a whole Sunday afternoon on one of the comfy sofas with a good novel or the Sunday papers while having some tea and then maybe a glass of wine or two. However,I think I would move on for dinner.

30Oy_Ipif0uwG_pNBLS9Mw.text: Yes definately posher that it's cafe name would suggest, I felt quite underdressed when I rocked up and saw the smart jacketed waiters. Food was delicious but I was starving and wolfed it all down with it barely touching the sides so I'm nto sure how qualified I am to comment. My favourite of the small plates were the lamb and the sea bass cerviche. I would probably skip the squid and chorizo, although they are two of my fav ingrediants the chorizo completely overwhelms the delicate squid reducing it to just another texture in tomatoey sauce. The pork belly (and this will probably sound like "duh, what did you expect from pork belly") was just too fatty. I think I'm over pork belly, it made me feel slightly sick although the crackling was lovely and crispy. Best dessert undoubtably the chocolate semifreddo, my friend definately "won" the dessert round! But overall very nice, and I would go back.

Nd7N-3jrd_pSlRPhH2fFiA.text: I got to know about this place from the Kaffeine blog (kaffeinelondon.blogspot.… and twitter.com/kaffeinelond… ) some weeks ago. Finally on a sunny bank holiday I decided to give it a try, and as it was just two weeks after the Riding House Cafe opened I was happy to get 50% off the food. When I entered the Riding House Cafe I was actually surprised. It is very light inside, it did not look like that when I looked over there sometimes while sitting in Kaffeine. The interior looks a bit old fashioned, but that's part of the concept I guess. In general it looks like a nice place, though I was happy to sit on a cozy sofa. The waiters are very friendly and always keep your glass of water full. Nice detail. I tried the cheese burger and it was really good. But in my opinion at least the burgers are a bit overpriced. You could get better burgers for less money in London. So I am not completely convinced that the burger are worth the price, but with 50% off it definitely was and in general it tasted quite good. But what were even better than the burger itself were the hand-crafted chips that came with it!And the rose wine I had for my lunch was actually not expensive, and I would say it's worth going there to just enjoy the rose wine at a sunny day.But what definitely even topped the rose wine was the Chocolate Praline Semi Freddo. Simply delicious - and not pricy at all! So, if you want to spend some time at the Riding House Cafe and not spend a lot of money on food, go there for a rose wine and a dessert. It's delicious for a very good price! :)I will definitely go there again for the rose and the dessert ... Oh, and one more thing: I also had the impression that it's a bit a posher place ... but somehow not too posh actually.

CfVoLtxY7BG4-o1tNwouBw.text: I might just have to move in. I don't remember the last time I was in a cafe SO DARN PRETTY. It's seriously beautiful in here. I'm smitten with the details, and even the petrol blue chairs lining the bar got me excited. I loved that there was the same blue dotted about the place - in the candles, in the water glasses. The attention to detail here is impressive. We didn't eat, but I did order some fresh mint tea (I was hungover, you see). Turns out that fresh mint tea is basically mint leaves in hot water. And I'd have mocked at the £2.40 price tag if it hadn't rid me of my sloshly sickly hungover tummy. Magic. The only annoying thing? Water pourers. This is something that's happening more and more in London, and I hate it. There's a jug of water on the table. We have arms. I can pour my own water. I don't need anyone popping back when I've put my glass down to top me up. If I wanted more water, I'd pour more water. It's hard to have a conversation when someone is hovering about the table. And weirdly, the service wasn't particularly attentive the rest of the time. I will come back and eat here, in fact, I can't wait. But I really hope that the service has sorted itself out when I do - it's not quite there yet and the cafe is too pretty to have sub-par service.

k6siWbne4nYFy8xjIb9ZOg.text: Nice, but not worth travelling across London for perhaps. Pleasant environment and charming staff but food is not brilliant - couple of examples are the chicken wings are smothered in sloppy BBQ / ketchup sauce which ruins the crunch and means you can't use the good blue cheese sauce, steak tartare is more caper and onion than meat, burger was over-cooked when we are asked for medium.  Lovely desserts - chocolate fondant especially good.

VFFqhYmKu1xTmyA92PzE3A.text: We just wondered in here late on a saturday afternoon and got a table fairly easily.We did have to wait at the bar for 20 mins first though, during which time the bar man was more interested in some younger women and never bothered to serve us, rude!I also specifically asked for no gherkin on my burger, what did I get? a Gherkin, I sometimes wonder if they do this out of a genuine mistake or if they are being arrogant...

MzbDJfdJ2-DVxMvkqYVn6A.text: I really loved the interior of this place. If I were working nearby I'd go here for breakfast, brunch, lunch, coffee and meetings! This is of course very subjective, but I felt that both by the bar counter, the various tables and the seats by the window I'd be happy to stay, spending my time.
