The interior just very nice, feels cosy and comfortable. Food-wise I thought The Riding House was good but I this was during the 50% off phase so if I had had the same amount of food afterwards I'm sure it would have been fairly expensive.

Q9Q07c1nvhAkzmT8Wf5PNQ.text: Having read glowing reviews in the Telegraph, we thought we'd give it a try.Having made a reservation on a Friday, we turned up promptly. Admittedly, it's probably the busiest night of the week and were told our table was paying up and asked to wait by the bar. Having ordered two bottles of wine between 6 of us, we hung around the bar for about 15 mins before asking how much longer our table would be. We were told that it was being set up so we headed back to the bar, expecting to be called at any moment. Another 10 mins passed and still nothing. Having approached one of the hosts again, we were told that it was going to be a few more minutes. I hate being lied to by hosts.35 mins after our alloted reservation, we were finally seated at our table in the main dining room. The waitress did apologise for the wait before giving out menus.We ordered a selection of small tapas-style dishes to all share and then main courses each.The salted cod croquettes were nice but a little cold by the time it arrived. The roast pork belly was delicious  crispy skin and tender meat. The goats cheese curd (seemingly ultra popular and trendy right now) was also really tasty but the veal sausage was just so-so.My main course was the chorizo hash brown with poached egg  more of a brunch dish in my view  but was very good with a perfectly poached egg on top. Others liked about the foie gras burger (although one friend complained he couldn't taste or find the foie gras!!) and the accompanying french fries were top notch.A good wine list and inventive cocktails as well as a smattering of classic ones, the drinks were certainly flowing.In the end, we had a good time but perhaps that was because we were so hungry that everything tasted pretty good. Still, worth a try, perhaps on a quieter night!

5ilip-bM_obBFvaziYsdFw.text: We were hunting for a place for dinner near Oxford Circus and on our way we passed Riding House Cafe.  It appeared lively and with a good layout, but we were headed further down the road.  As we came to our intended destination, we decided that it being empty was not a good sign and decided to return here.  They were full with reservations but offered to sit us in their lounge area which we accepted.  The service was friendly and courteous.  They were well informed on the menu and with a little help guided us through a selection of small plates the made up our dinner.  I especially enjoyed the Goats curd, Pear & Honey; Braised Rabbit, & Chicken Liver Parfait.  Deserts as you might expect were also quite good.  My daughter said to let everyone know their Fish and Chips were very good too!

XJYDmxc56wA_KW4zWn1kwA.text: Great food, good food and superb service that really cares about customer satisfaction. Very very trendy right now with the 20 and 30 something professionals, who can afford the more premium, but not over the top prices.

se2l5BIL3FEocnHK_tg-Zg.text: From the team that brought you my favourite neighbourhood locals, The Garrison and Village East, comes the Riding House Cafe, an all day brasserie located in the heart of Fitzrovia. Sitting a few streets back from the hustle and bustle of Oxford Street, the Riding House Cafe is the perfect lunch spot after blitzing through the nearby high street stores. The Brasserie had a great ambiance - bright and airy, decked out with vintage decor which was reminiscent of The Garrison, and staff offering welcomed smiles as we came through the door. The menu was made up of small plates designed to be shared as starters, and a variety of mains which seemed to cover off all the major food groups and more. It was lunch time after all, and my friend and I were starving, so we ordered 5 starters, 2 mains and a side of mash - all washed down with a cold glass of Prosecco of course! Notably delicious were the Pork belly - nice flavours and great crackling, and the Chorizo with Squid. Oh my!! The sauce was so incredibly tasty, we shamefully asked for some bread so we could mop the sauce up like proper ladies that lunched, as opposed to licking the plate. For the mains, I definitely didn't have any food envy with my incredible Chorizo Hash topped with two wonderfully poached eggs. They were DELISH! To top off our meal, we ordered the hot fudge sundae to share. Rich with chocolate fudge sauce, and devilishly sweet from the chunks of honeycomb and macaroons, this was a glass of naughtiness. And we were defeated. Overall, the meal was very good at reasonable prices - especially with 50% off food during their soft openings offer which runs till the start of May. Service was swift and friendly, albeit hit and miss - but then again it was only day 2 since opening, so no doubt this will improve over the weeks to come. I look forward to coming back - this time to include some of their inviting cocktails that were on the menu. For full review and pictures, please visit gourmetbelly.wordpress.c…

hNqdOoZdVIYrjA25NIt0jQ.text: The interior is nice but a little confused, reminiscent of the coffee shop in Frasier but a little more shabby chic. The bathrooms are lovely and have nice products but seem to be Mad Men meets Steampunk.Met some friends for brunch, had the fish and chips, it was pretty good standard fish and chips, the tartare was good too. Tried to order a few different drinks but they were having problems with one of the chillers I think, so ended up just getting a slightly overpriced cider.My friends ordered the kedgeree, which looked amazing and a selection of the small plates which come in various sizes of small, but really are quite tiny on the whole.On the whole, I liked the place, and would recommend.

sETnt84F7KNekYdI3xrlSQ.text: I appreciate them trying to do a lower Manhattan knockoff in central London. Good attempt.

GuU7TcDCCfo4upLKiH6VTw.text: An adorable little venue with a large hearty brunch. I absolutely loved their full and proper british breakfast and I would give this place more stars were it not for my fellow brunchers who were less fond of their nauseating eggs royale and minuscule slice of grapefruit. The wait staff was very friendly and courteous, but it was difficult to get their attention.

6Io7FGD13npLJeEgAzUsqA.text: A friend and I enjoyed a late breakfast here on a Saturday. My friend had the chorizo hashbrowns and I had the English breakfast with some sourdough toast. Service was attentive and the prices were quite reasonable. Quality of the food was high, as was the comfort and design aesthetic of the space and proximity to Oxford Street. Probably an excellent spot to run away from the holiday shopping crowds!

lfyR_fFX-8IW2d_I1ZINpg.text: A co-worker recommended the Riding House Cafe a few weeks back so I decided to give this new restaurant a try.  It started as a not-so-great experience and if it hadnt' been so...I would have given 5 stars.  I realize that image is everything w/a restaurant and you want your hostesses to be hot/fashionable/fabulous...but the 4 girls manning the table just seemed self-absorbed and obnoxious.  I asked if we could get a table and she said the wait was 45 minutes.  When I asked about the bar,  it was like a game of telephone...she looked to the girl at her left...who looked to the girl to her left...who looked to the girl to her left.  The girl on the FAR left looks to the girl on her right....and says 30 minutes...who in turn looks to the girl to her right........you get the point.  She couldn't speak to me directly....guess she was the most senior hostess and didn't deal with customers.  They were very rude and lacking in any sort of pleasent customer service.  My boyfriend could see that I was annoyed so he jumped in and they said they would call us when a spot at the bar was ready.  We headed to the pub across the street (which was great with a VERY nice barman...not pretentious at all I must say) and enjoyed a couple pints.  When we hadn't heard from them...we walked back over about 45 minutes later.  They had forgotten about us but had a table ready so I moved on from my silent rage.Once we got sat down,  the experience changed.  Our server was lovely and very well informed about the menu.  The food was FANTASTIC...I would go so far as to say the best I have had in London since moving here a year ago. I enjoyed the 8 oz Aberdeen Angus Sirloin Steak with Bernaise Sauce which was AMAZING.   On the side, we enjoyed roast butternut squash with chilli and sage.  These were one of the highlights of the meal as they had the density of potatoes and were flavored beautifully!  The restaurant itself is very upscale but doesn't present itself that way.  It is decorated in a very modern yet rustic way with wood long tables and amazing lighting.  I would definitely go back as the food is worth the headache of the hostest staff.

pmIApVZhpF4kMndCQrRmYA.text: I've been here several times for brunch, and every time it's been very good. Portions are perfect for a hungry weekend breakfast appetite, offer is of good quality and arrives hot, and the OJ is very healthy and refreshing. Would definitely recommend for those lazy Sunday morning when a good breakfast is in order. Book to get a decent table!

jHD5_gBjF1z_Vle0D3E7xw.text: Good food. Better for tapas like dishes at the bar. The service is very slow and the restaurant was very hot!

QQqDOftFh5KTvuS3XlTM6g.text: The lunch and dinner menu is more substantial than the Cafe moniker might suggest. Plates of small sharing food occupy the top half of the menu, neatly priced at £3, £4 or £5, a popular recent trend and here pleasingly priced. It's a bit all over the shop with no clear style; Moroccan nestles with continental bistro classics, Eastern treats sit next to solid British bites. That being said, there are some simple gems there and it's easy to eat substantially for £12 - £15, priced well for the local office market as a weekly treat. I'd have trouble defining anything as perfect, but there's nothing that doesn't need just a small tweak from the army of chefs on show. Squid and chorizo came in a spicy tomato sauce with fresh olives, slightly too many flavours for the well cooked but subtle squid. Roasted butternut squash with sage and (sadly unnoticeable) chilli should have had a little more crisp to it for my money, but for three quid it's hard to complain. Other 'smalls' sampled include a very competent lamb with a superbly spicy aubergine puree and a tasty if slightly dry pork belly - three big cubes made a good enough impression for me to put it down to teething troubles and a minute too long under the heat lamps. The final two dishes continue the slightly odd world tour. Tuna ceveche, that lime 'cooked' tartare from Latin America, was another substantial portion well doused in spice and flavour (though lacking a little in lime according to The International Man of Mystery), and a steak tartare, a favourite of mine, here slightly over 'prepared' (ie pre-mixed with a touch too many capers, onions and herbs), it was difficult for the beef to shine, but I'd certainly give it another go.Spread over two lunches, I also had time to sample the Tichfield Burger. An all too rarely seen sloppy mix of darkly pink flesh (I didn't stop and get the breakdown, no doubt others will) cooked medium and nestled plumply on a controversially seeded (and slightly too chewy) bun. It wasn't the worst bun I've had, and was certainly of a good quality, but didn't quite ring true. The meat was excellent. The Tichfield comes topped with a fairly proportioned slice of grilled foie and thinly sliced and slow braised onions, both rendering down and sinking into the juicy meat like an upmarket sloppy joe.

M29aQf_EKstbwWXTEwzkkg.text: I can walk to the Riding House Cafe in about 7 minutes, which is very dangerous for me as it means I tend to go more than I should probably! As a massive breakfast fan, the Riding House Cafe just has everything I need  impeccably polite staff (well, most of the time), great food and delicious smoothies served in glass milk bottles. The decor is just fabulous  I rather like the fact that it doesn't look very impressive from the outside, but when you walk inside it blows your mind! My particular favourites are probably the pink window downstairs where you can spy on the chefs and the disturbing stuffed squirrels holding up the lamps. If you're going for breakfast, get the avocado on toast and the sunshine smoothie. Sorted.

E6R7xjBhkzXfMN5ZNIv5kw.text: I quite liked The Riding House Cafe. I've been here twice so far, primarily because of their opening 50% off food offer, and enjoyed both times I've been here. Food: I like the sharing dishes concept. It allows those of us who want loads of variety to pick all sorts of different kinds of dishes and still keep the costs down. The stand-out dishes, for me, were the roasted pork belly (yummy!), the bread (four thick slices, artichoke dip, all for £1.50 before discount), and the fries that accompanied the Titchfield Burger. The Titchfield Burger in itself was pretty decent, in that I enjoyed it, but, as I'm not a burger connoisseur, and I'd been off meat for a week, you've got to realise I'm not able to give an objective opinion. All I can say was that it came medium rare, it was soft and juicy, it fell apart easily when I cut it, and it more than satisfied my meat cravings, even if the foie gras bit of it was a little hard to find! My Irish friend ordered a whole bunch of oysters and proclaimed them delicious and fantastically priced even at the full price of £2 a piece. Dessert: We shared a chocolate praline semifreddo. That was easily the best part of the meal, even if it took a while to come. The raspberry sauce went very well with the praline, and I loved the nut brittle which came with it. Coffee: I think the coffee comes from Caravan and it was incredible. It could certainly rival the (very good) coffee shop opposite, that's for sure! Decor: Woodsy, relaxed and yet still a little upmarket. Certainly more posh than the 'cafe' part of the name would suggest. Service: Waiters are nice and friendly, although service can be a little on the relaxed side. Our dessert arrived after I finished my coffee, which was a bit of a let-down. Tables have a two hour turnaround which is strictly enforced. My friend and I were shifted to the main bar area once our two hours were up. Verdict: Loved the place, was fantastic value at half-price, would still be pretty good value at full price. Great place to come and relax and just catch up with friends. Just make sure to finish all the food before your two hours are up!

WAejbN5vGB5dUJoKzBYMuQ.text: I loved the Riding House Cafe - indeed I would be there eating dinner right now had I not been laid low with horrible flu virus for ages and forced to cancel all my nights out. Sigh. But I really enjoyed my dinner there the night before the dreaded lurgy struck... we went late, after a comedy show and there was a great, buzzy atmosphere. We had booked, but had to wait at the bar for about 15 minutes which was fine, although I was in need of food..anyway we decided to order 3 of the veggie sides between us (roasted root veg, cabbage with chestnut butter and a luscious mac'n'cheese; a great deal for £10) and some fat, juicy prawns with mayo. It was all delicious and left enough room for a majestic chocolate fondant, really oozy and liquid in the centre, exactly how I like it. My friend had hers with the advertised coconut icecream which she said was great too. I'll definitely be going again - once I've knocked the flu on the head. In the meantime, there is some emergency pumpkin cheesecake in the freezer.
